narrative=Arthur McCarthy, an 85-year-old retired travel agency manager, was last seen near his home on North Road, Insch, AB52 6XP. His daughter reported him missing when he failed to return from his regular walking route. Arthur, who occasionally enjoyed visiting the nearby synagogue, had unintentionally wandered onto A939, Corgarff, AB36 8YL, disoriented due to his condition. The police traced him to Bridgend of Glenlivet, having safely found his way to local residents who assisted him.

narrative=Arthur McCarthy was last reported leaving the synagogue near his residence on Bog Road. According to his daughter, he mentioned going to visit a friend in Banchory but never arrived. Concern quickly escalated due to Arthur's age and existing disabilities. A search commenced, focusing on familiar routes he might take, including Inchmarlo Road and the A939, known paths from his travel days. His colleague, Dennis Shaw, helped coordinate the search efforts along these possible routes. Thankfully, Arthur was located by attentive staff at a shop on Dee Street in Banchory. He was disoriented but unharmed and safely reunited with his family.

narrative=Arthur McCarthy, an experienced sea kayaker despite his age, was last known to be preparing for a solo kayaking trip along the rugged coastline near Carmelite Street, Banff, AB45 1GF. Arthur had often expressed his love for the sea to his friend Rachel McCarthy, who became concerned when he failed to return home to North Road, Insch, AB52 6XP after the planned excursion. Initially dismissed as a possible minor oversight, concerns grew when Arthur did not contact anyone as usual. Rachel, unable to reach him, contacted local authorities, emphasizing the potential for a sea kayaking accident, especially given the unpredictable tides and currents along that stretch of coast. After an intensive search that involved coast guard resources, Arthur was traced safely on Golden Knowes Road, having gone off course but managing to navigate safely back to land.
